stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the geometry and texturing of the game's overworld, focusing on a specific cave area. During the stream, he struggles to recall a key gameplay mechanic, discusses his game design philosophies, details his YouTube sponsorship strategy, and shares personal frustrations with German bureaucracy.

development_findings.summary: Kaze articulates a core design philosophy that creating enjoyable Mario 64 hacks is fundamentally easier than Zelda hacks, as Mario's movement is inherently fun, whereas Zelda requires deep puzzle and narrative design.
development_findings.quote: When you make a Mario 64 hack you don't have to really design the game... When you make a Zelda hack you have to actually design the puzzles, the story, everything. It is so much harder to actually make a fun Zelda game than it is to make a fun Mario game.

development_findings.summary: A frustrating pit in a cave area was identified as overly punishing. The planned solution is to add small platforms to make recovery easier and less frustrating for the player.
development_findings.quote: Oh my god, if I fell in here I would lose it. I would lose my cool. We can't have this in the game.

development_findings.summary: A key gameplay mechanic for a star in the overworld involves the player carrying a crystal which reveals a temporary, walkable path around Mario.
development_findings.quote: the idea was there would be a crystal here and while you hold the crystal a path around mario appears and you can only attack with the path while you are holding the crystal

development_findings.summary: A one-way mirror effect is used to visually connect the overworld to the interior of a course, making the game world feel more cohesive.
development_findings.quote: in Course 3, there is this mirror here that reflects the level back at you, and then in the overworld, there is this where you can look through the mirror. So basically, it's like a one-way mirror into the level.

development_findings.summary: The game is approaching a releasable state, but Kaze intends to continue polishing it without a defined endpoint for this phase.
development_findings.quote: we're almost in a state Where we would be able to just release the game. But there is still some polishing I want to do.

development_findings.summary: The beta testing phase is focused on gathering feedback on the overall gameplay experience and fun factor, rather than technical bug hunting.
development_findings.quote: It's gameplay testing. Not bug testing. So I want you to just play the game As you normally would.

development_findings.summary: The project is dependent on the wider SM64 decompilation community tools, as Kaze is waiting for an external team to fix a bug in the `fast64` plugin rather than addressing it himself.
development_findings.quote: that's still a bug in first 64, not much I can do about it. I can just wait for them to fix it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's current focus on creating more YouTube content is driven by financial necessity and sponsorship obligations with Squarespace.
context_findings.quote: I've been putting in a lot of work and I'm making more videos recently. Because I need to make more videos. Because I need to feed my family.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is experiencing significant personal stress due to an unresolved tax issue with the German Finansamt, complicated by an unresponsive tax advisor.
context_findings.quote: I am in this fucked up situation. Where I think I did everything right. But I have no proof for it. And there's no way for me to find out.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong dislike for being broadly categorized as a "Nintendo person," distinguishing between different Nintendo fandoms which he perceives differently.
context_findings.quote: I do not want to be known as a Nintendo person, please. Nintendo person is like a slur almost.

context_findings.summary: Kaze values rational debate and the ability for either party to admit fault, believing most arguments stem from simple misunderstandings of semantics or ethics.
context_findings.quote: I can actually argue with people. And then after the argument, the person can be like, dang, dude, I was wrong. Or I can argue with people. And at the end of the argument, I can be like, dang, I was wrong. Dude, that's a fucking talent.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a firm business principle of only accepting flat-rate sponsorships, viewing conversion-based deals as a scam that unfairly shifts all financial risk onto the creator.
context_findings.quote: I would never take a conversion space deal... Otherwise I'm the one taking on all the risk for your product. Obviously I'm not doing that. What kind of idiot would take on all the risk?

context_findings.summary: Kaze anticipates that his next major endeavor after the current project will be developing his own original game with a new IP.
context_findings.quote: It is more likely that after RTY I have to make my own games, my own IP entirely, which I have ideas for.

biobak.summary: Biobak has reportedly completed the art and texture work for Course 2.
biobak.quote: I think Biobak also finished course 2.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for reworking the textures in Course 3, which Kaze feels are currently subpar.
biobak.quote: we're also probably still gonna rework quest 3 at least the texture selection because some of it is kind of rough right now

biobak.summary: Kaze relies on Biobak as a source of project knowledge, suggesting he might remember a forgotten gameplay idea when Kaze could not.
biobak.quote: Yeah, Biobak might be the one to know.

badub.summary: Kaze solicits "OST wishes" from his audience, indicating that Badub's music is integrated into the project and available to be played during development streams.

key_stories.title: The Forgotten Crystal Star
key_stories.summary: While working on a cave area, Kaze realized he had forgotten the central gameplay mechanic for its star. After a frustrating search, a hint from his chat helped him remember the complete idea: a mission where carrying a crystal reveals a temporary path.
key_stories.challenge: A key gameplay idea for a star in the overworld was completely forgotten and not documented.
key_stories.process: Kaze struggled to remember the mechanic, fruitlessly searched old stream VODs, and discussed the problem with his live chat. A viewer provided a key hint ('gargoyle') that jogged Kaze's memory, allowing him to recall the full concept.
key_stories.outcome: The idea was successfully recovered and the design for the area was solidified. The mechanic involves carrying a crystal that reveals a temporary path for Mario.
key_stories.key_quote: oh that's the idea okay so the idea was there would be a crystal here and while you hold the crystal a path around mario appears

key_stories.title: The German Tax Nightmare
key_stories.summary: Kaze described his ongoing, stressful struggle with the German tax office. His hired tax advisor has become unresponsive, leaving Kaze unable to verify if a past issue was resolved or even to access his own tax information, creating a bureaucratic nightmare.
key_stories.challenge: Resolving an ambiguous tax problem with the German government from Canada while being unable to contact the tax advisor who holds all the information.
key_stories.process: Kaze hired a tax advisor in Germany to handle his finances. An unspecified problem arose, which the advisor claimed to have fixed. However, the advisor has since become unresponsive, leaving Kaze without access to his own tax account or any official correspondence.
key_stories.outcome: The situation remains unresolved, causing Kaze significant stress and financial uncertainty. He is left in limbo, unable to verify his tax status or communicate with the authorities.
key_stories.key_quote: I am in this fucked up situation. Where I think I did everything right. But I have no proof for it. And there's no way for me to find out.

key_stories.title: Sponsorship and Creator Risk
key_stories.summary: Kaze detailed his business philosophy on sponsorships, explaining why he only accepts flat-rate deals. He used a rejected offer from Gamerfuel as an example of a conversion-based deal that he considers a scam for forcing creators to shoulder all the risk.
key_stories.challenge: Needing to monetize content creation in a financially stable way without accepting exploitative deals.
key_stories.process: Kaze contrasted his current flat-rate sponsorship with Squarespace against a conversion-based offer from another company. He explained his refusal of the latter, arguing that such deals unfairly place all the business risk on the creator rather than the company whose product is being advertised.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze has a stable, flat-rate sponsorship with Squarespace that funds his video creation, but he is aware the contract is finite and he will need to find a new sponsor.
key_stories.key_quote: I would never take a conversion based deal. They pay me 2500 flat per video basically... Otherwise I'm the one taking on all the risk for your product. Obviously I'm not doing that.
